DeployR JasperReports Server Client Library

A simple Java library for integrating DeployR capabilities into Jaspersoft's JasperReports Server BI Suite.

See: Description

Packages 
Package Description
com.revo.deployr.client.jasper
Central package, defines a DeployR-aware Jasper Report Query Executer.
com.revo.deployr.client.jasper.factory
Defines RQueryExecuter factory for new "deployrScript" query language.

A simple Java library for integrating DeployR capabilities into Jaspersoft's JasperReports Server BI Suite.

1. RQueryExecuter

This library provides an implementation of a DeployR-aware JRQueryExecuter. This query executer generates an RDataSource. This data source can be used to integrate R session data generated by a DeployR R Script execution into a Jasper Report.

2. Custom Query Language: deployrScript

The DeployR-aware custom Query Executer supports a new custom query language, deployrScript.

This query language allows the report user to configure and connect to a DeployR-aware JRDataSource. The following is an example of a deployrScript report Query string: 

<deployr url="http://localhost:7300/deployr">
    <script filename="Histogram of Auto Sales" directory="sample" author="testuser"/>
    <preload>
        <workspace repo="testuser" directory="sample" name="dataset.rData"/>
        <directory repo="testuser" directory="sample" name="population.csv" version="1327229341753"/>
    </preload>
    <robjects>
        <robject name="title"/>
        <robject name="sales"/>
        <robject name="forecasts"/>
    </robjects>
    <authentication username="testuser" password="secret"/>
</deployr>
The preload, robjects and authentication elements in this query markup are all optional and should be set according to the specific needs of the report and the R Script being executed. Within the preload element both the workspace and directory elements are optional and the version attribute on those two elements is also optional.


3. Defining Report Fields using the RDataSource

The DeployR-aware DataSource exposes a single record that can be queried for R session data returned on the execution of an R Script.

Each data item present on the DataSource can be referenced by a unique identifier. Each data item also has an associated data type. By combining type and identifier in a simple query syntax a report designer can extract data from the DataSource for rendering. The query syntax language is detailed here:

For each field in the report the Description property should be specified as follows:

type : identifier : optional-attributes

3a. Primitive data types that can be indicated by type, are listed here:

string, integer, double, boolean, date

Example: Defining a field with description property of string:title would extract the item title from the data source for rendering.

3b. Collection data types that can be indicated by type, are listed here:

vector, matrix, factor

Vector and factor types take an index as an optional-attribute that indexes into the vector to retrieve a specific value. Matrix types take a row and an index as optional-attributes that index into the matrix to retrieve a specific value. If these optional-attributes are omitted on the field description then the complete List for the collection is returned.

Example: Defining a field with description property of vector:sales:0 would extract the vector item sales from the data source and render the first data element.

3c. Complex data types that can be indicated by type, are listed here:

list, dataframe

Complex data types do not themselves represent data but rather they encapsulate data. To access data encapsulated in a complex data type simply apply the query syntax recursively.

Example: Defining a field with description property of dataframe:forecasts:vector:quaterly:4 would extract the data associated with the quaterly vector that is encapsulated within the forecasts dataframe.

3d. File data type. There is one single file type that can be specified to return the URL string for the item indicated by identifier.

Example: Defining a field with description property of file:sales.png would extract the URL string of the file indicated.

4. Handling R Script Inputs as Report Parameters

There are times when a user might want to supply additional data that will be passed as inputs on an R Script such as a flag indicating a condition that determines the path of execution in the R Script.

These inputs are supported by Revolution Report Parameters (RRP). A RQueryExecuter based report can specify any number of DeployR-specific report parameters that can be relayed as inputs to the R Script. These DeployR-specific report parameters are identified by prefixing RRP_ ahead of each parameter name in the report definition.

Example: An R Script expects two inputs: a boolean flag and a number, let's call them retired and age respectively. These inputs configure the behavior of the script each time it is run. To specify these report parameters in order that they will be identified and forwarded to the R Script each named parameter needs to be prefixed with RRP_.

The required report parameter names would then be RRP_retired and RRP_age respectively. As these report parameters are expected to be supplied by the user only primitive types for these parameters are allowed.

5. Changes from the Jaspersoft-DeployR BI 1.0 Client Library release

The preload attribute on the deployr element in the 1.0 release has been replaced with a new preload element as indicated above. This new element supports the preloading of binary R data directly into the workspace using the workspace element and the preloading of file data into the working directory of the R session using the directory element.

The files element supported in the 1.0 release is no longer required. Now any named file artifact created by the execution of the R script can be referenced simply by using the file type as detailed above.
